Stable Boundary Layers with Subsidence: Scaling and Similarity of the Truly Steady State

Thijs Bon â€ƒâ€ƒ RaÃºl BayoÃ¡n Cal â€ƒâ€ƒ Johan Meyers
(Received: DD Month YEAR / Accepted: DD Month YEAR)
Abstract

The stable boundary layer (SBL) subjected to large-scale subsidence is studied through large-eddy simulations (LESs) with fixed surface temperature and a linear subsidence velocity profile. These boundary layers reach a truly steady state, where thermal equilibrium is established by a balance between surface cooling and subsidence-induced heating. We identify three governing dimensionless groups by scaling the governing equations with the geostrophic wind and Coriolis frequency, and systematically investigate the impact of these external parameters on global flow properties and mean profiles in the steady state. The SBL depth, low-level jet, and the magnitude of the turbulent momentum flux are reduced when the subsidence rate or Buoyancy number increases, while surface heat flux is enhanced. The shape of normalized mean profiles of temperature and heat flux is mainly determined by the subsidence rate, while they collapse for varying buoyancy and surface Rossby numbers. We develop empirical correlations for the stability parameter hÎ¸/LOsubscriptâ„ğœƒsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‚h_{\theta}/L_{O}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a thermal shape factor, and propose a new unidirectional geostrophic drag law, to form a closed set of equations that estimates relevant flow properties from external parameters. The estimation errors compared to the LES data are less than 5% for friction velocity and surface heat flux, and at most 10% for the SBL depth hÎ¸subscriptâ„ğœƒh_{\theta}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Within the surface layer, dimensionless velocity and temperature gradients in the steady SBL with subsidence show acceptable agreement to Moninâ€“Obukhov similarity theory, while the collapse is improved when a recently proposed mixed scaling parameter, that includes hÎ¸/LOsubscriptâ„ğœƒsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‚h_{\theta}/L_{O}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is used.

1 Introduction

One of the key challenges in atmospheric and environmental sciences is understanding of the stable boundary layer (SBL), which is relevant to the renewable energy sector, air quality and pollutant dispersion, numerical weather prediction and climate modelling (e.g. Steeneveld (2014), McWilliams etÂ al. (2023), and references therein). The atmospheric boundary layer (ABL) commonly exhibits stable stratification during nighttime over land (also referred to as the nocturnal boundary layer or NBL), due to radiative cooling of the surface. SBLs can further be generated by advection of warm air over a colder surface, for example in maritime areas or in the polar regions. The main processes that govern the structure of the SBL are radiation, turbulence, horizontal advection and subsidence (Stull 1988; Wyngaard 2010).

Subsidence, large-scale downward movement of air, and as a consequence near-surface flow divergence, is often associated with synoptic high-pressure systems, fair weather conditions and clear skies (Carlson and Stull 1985). Furthermore, polar areas experience persistent subsidence due to planetary-scale circulations (Holton 2004). Motivated by the relatively small magnitude of these vertical motions compared to horizontal velocity components and the difficulty to accurately measure them, subsidence is often neglected in numerical investigations of the SBL (Mirocha and KosoviÄ‡ 2010; Stoll etÂ al. 2020). However, early observational studies already concluded that the heating rate associated with subsidence can be as large as the cooling rates due to turbulence and radiation (Carlson and Stull 1985; Mirocha etÂ al. 2005), and should therefore not be neglected. In the present study, we investigate the SBL under influence of subsidence and the related steady state regime through an extensive set of large-eddy simulations (LESs). Although effects of subsidence on the SBL have been investigated previously, a systematic analysis of the full parameter space that plays a role in the SBL with subsidence has not been performed before.

In a stably stratified environment, subsidence brings down warm air from aloft, thereby reducing the boundary-layer height and affecting the atmospheric heat balance (Stull 1988). This can affect many other physical processes, such as dispersion of pollutants (Shi etÂ al. 2022), and growth/ablation of a snow/ice pack due to changes in surface heat flux (Mirocha and KosoviÄ‡ 2010). Moreover, the formation of marine boundary layer clouds, which poses a significant source of uncertainty in climate models, is influenced by subsidence (Bellon and Stevens 2012; Chung etÂ al. 2012). Prior work has demonstrated that incorporating atmospheric subsidence into numerical simulations improves the agreement with measurement data of the SBL over the Arctic Ocean (Mirocha and KosoviÄ‡ 2010) and the Antarctic Plateau (Vignon etÂ al. 2017b; vanÂ der Linden etÂ al. 2019). Other studies highlight the importance of including subsidence in modelling of the unstable boundary layer over both land (Blay-Carreras etÂ al. 2014; Rey-Sanchez etÂ al. 2021) and sea (Mazzitelli etÂ al. 2014).

The LES study of Mirocha and KosoviÄ‡ (2010), which was based on observations from the Surface Heat Budget of the Arctic Ocean field experiment (SHEBA), showed that the addition of subsidence reduces vertical momentum fluxes while enhancing vertical heat flux, increases temperature gradients, and limits the growth of the boundary layer, leading to a â€œnearly steady boundary layer behaviour during periods of constant forcingâ€. More recently, L19 performed centimetre-scale LESs of a weakly and very stable boundary layer and compared results to observational data from the Dome C station on the Antarctic Plateau, where the absence of the diurnal cycle during the Antarctic winter facilitated the examination of a long-lived SBL. They concluded that the inclusion of subsidence can result in a truly steady SBL, where the turbulent cooling towards the surface is balanced by the heating due to subsidence. This statistically steady state, characterized by a thermal equilibrium (see section 2.1), is the main focus in the present study. We note that the term â€œequilibriumâ€ here should not be confused with equilibrium in developing turbulent boundary layers, which describes a situation where the normalized flow properties do not longer depend on streamwise position (Devenport and Lowe 2022).

In typical investigations of the SBL through LES or direct numerical simulation (DNS), a true steady state is never reached. Many of these studies are based on the well-documented case setup of the Global Energy and Water Cycle Experiment Atmospheric Boundary Layer Study 1 (GABLS1, Beare etÂ al. (2006)), which currently is still used as a reference case to e.g., validate new LES codes (Van Heerwaarden etÂ al. 2017), evaluate new subgrid models or surface parametrizations (Matheou and Chung 2014; Maronga etÂ al. 2020; Dai etÂ al. 2021) and assess grid-size sensitivity of LES models (Maronga and Li 2022). Slightly modified configurations have been used to study effects of increasing stability (Huang and Bou-Zeid 2013; Sullivan etÂ al. 2016; Narasimhan etÂ al. 2023), heterogeneous surface temperatures (Stoll and PortÃ©-Agel 2009; Mironov and Sullivan 2016), or interactions between the SBL and wind farms (Allaerts and Meyers 2018; Strickland etÂ al. 2022). The GABLS1 setup is characterized by a constant cooling rate as the lower boundary condition, meaning that the surface temperature keeps decreasing in time. In studies that employ DNS to study the SBL, there is more variety in the surface temperature boundary condition, involving either a prescribed surface heat flux (e.g. Nieuwstadt 2005; Flores and Riley 2011; Gohari and Sarkar 2017), fixed bottom temperature (Ansorge and Mellado 2014; Shah and Bou-Zeid 2014), or a combination thereof (Gohari and Sarkar 2018). Because the surface cooling is not compensated by any heat source, none of the simulations in the aforementioned studies reaches a truly steady state, where both the turbulent and thermal energy of the system are in (statistical) equilibrium. The â€œquasi-steadyâ€ state that the SBL reaches after a finite time is commonly employed, in which the mean profiles of velocity and turbulence statistics remain constant while only the temperature profile keeps changing. This quasi-steady period is then used to analyze results and compare cases, while the domain-averaged temperature still declines (see Eq. (1)). In numerous applications however, it is desired to have long averaging times under truly stationary conditions, without any transient effects, to permit more systematic analysis and comparison of multiple different simulations. For example, the study of large-scale secondary motions that can be induced by heterogeneous surface roughness or temperatures, requires long averaging times (Bon and Meyers 2022; Castro etÂ al. 2021; SchÃ¤fer etÂ al. 2022). When employing LES for a systematic analysis of the effects of large wind farms on atmospheric heat fluxes, examination of stationary statistics considerably simplifies understanding (Sescu and Meneveau 2014; Maas and Raasch 2022). Moreover, in assessments of the sensitivity of an LES code to the grid spacing or the subgrid-scale model, constantly decreasing surface temperature in typical SBL simulations prevents using long averaging times (Maronga and Li 2022).

In the next section (2.1) , we start with a brief description of thermal equilibrium in the SBL with subsidence. The LES code and numerical methodology are subsequently outlined in Sect. 2.2. Based on dimensional analysis, we identify the relevant non-dimensional groups in Sect. 2.3, and perform a series of LESs where the surface temperature, subsidence rate and surface roughness are varied. The case setup can be roughly viewed as a combination of the GABLS1 case and the configuration used by L19, as further detailed in Sect. 2.4. Based on the LES results, we examine how the steady state depends on the relevant external parameters in Sect. 3. Different methods of estimating the SBL depth are compared in Sect. 3.2, followed by an investigation of scaled mean profiles (Sect. 3.3). In Sect. 3.4, a geostrophic drag law is proposed for the steady SBL with subsidence, and present model equations that accurately estimate global flow properties of interest based on external parameters. An assessment of the validity of the widely used Moninâ€“Obukhov similarity theory (MOST) in the presence of subsidence is given in Sect. 3.5. Finally, the main conclusions are summarized in Sect. 4.

Equation (4) shows that the SBL in our simplified framework reaches a steady state when the surface heat flux (left-hand side) is equal to the bulk heat flux due to subsidence heating (right-hand side), calculated as the integrated temperature deviation multiplied by the linear subsidence rate (Stull 1988, p. 515). Moreover, Eq. (2) shows that there is an explicit relation between mean profiles of temperature and turbulent heat flux. However, as pointed out by L19, the internal distribution of heat flux and temperature in the boundary layer, and likewise the surface heat flux, (thermal) boundary-layer height and mean temperature, remain unknown a priori. The set of simulations that we perform aims to shed light on relations between these parameters and assess similarity of mean profiles, as discussed in Sect. 3.3.

As described in the previous section, Î“wsubscriptÎ“ğ‘¤\mathrm{\Gamma}_{w}roman_Î“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the subsidence rate, i.e. the gradient of the subsidence velocity profile in sâˆ’1superscripts1\mathrm{s}^{-1}roman_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Following L19, we use the horizontally averaged vertical temperature gradient rather than the local one, and neglect horizontal velocity divergence in the momentum equation (see Appendix 1 in their work for justification). The subgrid-scale (SGS) fluxes Ï„iâ¢jsâ¢gâ¢ssuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ ğ‘”ğ‘ \tau_{ij}^{sgs}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_g italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and qjsâ¢gâ¢ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘ ğ‘”ğ‘ q_{j}^{sgs}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_g italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are modelled with the turbulent kinetic energy (TKE) model, based on Deardorff (1980), which may be the most widely used SGS model in LES (Gibbs and Fedorovich 2016; Stoll etÂ al. 2020). The modified filtered pressure pâ‹†superscriptğ‘â‹†{p}^{\star}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is in fact the deviation from the background pressure, divided by a reference density, and includes the trace of the subgrid stress tensor (Allaerts and Meyers 2015).

The governing equations (6)-(8) are solved using the SP-Wind solver, an in-house DNS/LES code developed over the past 15 years at KU Leuven. It has been widely used to study the interaction between wind-farms and the (stably) stratified Ekman layer (Goit and Meyers 2015; Allaerts 2016; Allaerts and Meyers 2018; Lanzilao and Meyers 2024), as well as stably stratified flows over thermally inhomogeneous surfaces (Bon etÂ al. 2023). In SP-Wind, time integration is performed using a classical fourth-order Rungeâ€“Kutta scheme with a fixed Courantâ€“Friedrichsâ€“Lewy (CFL) number of 0.4. The code employs pseudo-spectral discretization in the horizontal directions with the 3/2-dealiasing rule for the nonlinear terms, and a fourth-order energy conserving finite-difference scheme for the vertical direction (Verstappen and Veldman 2003). Consequently, the horizontal boundary conditions are periodic, while at the top of the domain symmetry conditions for horizontal velocity components and potential temperature ((âˆ‚(u,v,Î¸)/âˆ‚z=0(\partial({u},{v},{\theta})/\partial z=0( âˆ‚ ( italic_u , italic_v , italic_Î¸ ) / âˆ‚ italic_z = 0) are applied, and the vertical velocity (wğ‘¤{w}italic_w) is 0.

At the lower boundary of the domain, we apply MOST to model the surface fluxes for momentum and temperature. A note on using MOST as a boundary condition is presented in Appendix 3. The surface flux parametrization in MOST depends on the roughness lengths for momentum (z0â¢msubscriptğ‘§0ğ‘šz_{0m}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and heat (z0â¢hsubscriptğ‘§0â„z_{0h}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), and the fixed surface temperature Î¸s=Î¸âˆâˆ’Î”â¢Î¸subscriptğœƒğ‘ subscriptğœƒÎ”ğœƒ\theta_{s}=\theta_{\infty}-\mathrm{\Delta}\thetaitalic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Î” italic_Î¸. In order to limit our parameter space, we take z0â¢h=z0â¢m=z0subscriptğ‘§0â„subscriptğ‘§0ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘§0z_{0h}=z_{0m}=z_{0}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For further details on the SP-wind code, implementation of MOST and the TKE subgrid model, we refer to Allaerts (2016) and Allaerts and Meyers (2018). The latest version of SP-Wind employs a full 3-dimensional domain decomposition for efficient parallel computation, allowing to run the majority of simulations on 12 nodes, each containing 128 AMD Epyc 7763 cores in the HPC cluster of the Flemish Supercomputing Center (VSC).

To put these values into context, Carlson and Stull (1985) estimated horizontal divergence rates of 0.09âˆ’3.3Ã—10âˆ’50.093.3superscript1050.09-3.3\times 10^{-5}0.09 - 3.3 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT s-1 based on a field experiment in Oklahoma. (2019).

2.4.1 Initialization and Time Development

All simulations are initialized with a uniform velocity u=Gğ‘¢ğºu=Gitalic_u = italic_G in the xâˆ’limit-fromğ‘¥x-italic_x -direction, with random perturbation of 0.1â¢G0.1ğº0.1G0.1 italic_G added to the velocity components below hp=100subscriptâ„ğ‘100h_{p}=100italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 100 m to trigger turbulence. The initial temperature profile increases linearly from Î¸ssubscriptğœƒğ‘ \theta_{s}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to Î¸âˆ=Î¸s+Î”â¢Î¸subscriptğœƒsubscriptğœƒğ‘ Î”ğœƒ\theta_{\infty}=\theta_{s}+\mathrm{\Delta}\thetaitalic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Î” italic_Î¸ at hi=200subscriptâ„ğ‘–200h_{i}=200italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 200 m and is equal to Î¸âˆsubscriptğœƒ\theta_{\infty}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT above. In preliminary simulations, initial conditions were varied by e.g. changing the initial inversion height hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or starting from a constant temperature Î¸âˆsubscriptğœƒ\theta_{\infty}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and gradually cooling the surface temperature towards the final value Î¸ssubscriptğœƒğ‘ \theta_{s}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (similar to the DNSs of Gohari and Sarkar (2018) or LESs of L19 and Maronga etÂ al. (2020)). Crucially, the initial conditions did not have an effect on the mean profiles in the final equilibrium state, except the time needed to reach this steady state. Furthermore, in the latter scenario, a notably stronger inertial oscillation in the upper part of the domain was observed. This can be attributed to turbulent perturbations penetrating deeply into the neutral free atmosphere, leading to differences between the horizontal velocity components and geostrophic wind, consequently triggering the inertial oscillation (Blackadar 1957; vanÂ de Wiel etÂ al. 2010). By applying a temperature gradient up to a sufficient height from the onset of the simulations, there is a stably stratified layer above the initial turbulent perturbations, that prevents turbulence to enter into the neutral free atmosphere.

In all simulations, the amplitude of the inertial oscillation, quantified by considering the time development of âŸ¨uâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘¢\langle u\rangleâŸ¨ italic_u âŸ© and âŸ¨vâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘£\langle v\rangleâŸ¨ italic_v âŸ© averaged over the upper 25% of the domain, was smaller than 1% of the geostrophic wind GğºGitalic_G. Therefore, we were not required to use forced damping methods in the upper part of the domain, such as the geostrophic damping approach proposed by Stipa etÂ al. (2023) or the widely used Rayleigh Damping Layer (Klemp and Lily 1977; Lanzilao and Meyers 2022). The latter is commonly applied in numerical simulations to prevent spurious reflection of gravity waves at the upper boundary, but unnecessary here due to the unstratified free atmosphere.

To assess whether a simulation has reached thermal equilibrium, the instantaneous sum of the surface heat flux and the domain-integrated subsidence heating are diagnosed as:

In the remainder of the text, all variables can be assumed to be time-averaged and in the statistically steady state.

2.4.2 Resolution and Domain Size

All simulations are performed on a domain of LxÃ—LyÃ—Lz=4003subscriptğ¿ğ‘¥subscriptğ¿ğ‘¦subscriptğ¿ğ‘§superscript4003L_{x}\times L_{y}\times L_{z}=400^{3}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 400 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ m, equal to the GABLS1 configuration. The maximum boundary-layer depth hâ„hitalic_h of approximately 200Â m in our cases is also comparable, although it is smaller in most cases (see next section and Table 1). To assess the sensitivity to domain size, two simulations of case S3T2Z2 were run, where the respective horizontal and vertical dimensions were doubled, which had negligible effect on mean profiles of first and second order statistics. The only observable difference was in the peak of the turbulent temperature fluctuation âŸ¨Î¸â€²â£2âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğœƒâ€²2\langle{\theta^{\prime 2}}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© that occurs at the height of the inversion layer (not shown), for the case where the horizontal domain size was doubled. This peak in temperature variance is assumed to be related to internal waves in the very stable capping inversion (Saiki etÂ al. 2000; Lloyd etÂ al. 2022). As already argued by Beare etÂ al. (2006), domain lengths of multiple kilometres would be required to catch the full extent of these gravity waves, which is beyond the interest of the present work.

Regarding resolution, a grid size of 128Ã—128Ã—256128128256128\times 128\times 256128 Ã— 128 Ã— 256 points is utilized, corresponding to a horizontal grid spacing of Î”x=Î”y=3.125subscriptÎ”ğ‘¥subscriptÎ”ğ‘¦3.125\mathrm{\Delta}_{x}=\mathrm{\Delta}_{y}=3.125roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3.125 m and Î”z=1.56subscriptÎ”ğ‘§1.56\mathrm{\Delta}_{z}=1.56roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1.56 m in the vertical direction. Allaerts (2016) is followed by using a finer resolution in the vertical direction than in the horizontal, as is common for codes with pseudo-spectral discretization in horizontal directions (e.g. Stoll and PortÃ©-Agel 2009; Huang and Bou-Zeid 2013).

Because increasing stratification leads to a decrease in TKE, the dependency on the grid resolution and SGS model is amplified in simulations where the stability is stronger (Sullivan etÂ al. 2016; vanÂ der Linden etÂ al. 2019). Therefore, the grid sensitivity is evaluated for the three scenarios exhibiting the strongest stratification, as measured by stability parameter hÎ¸/LOsubscriptâ„ğœƒsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‚h_{\theta}/L_{O}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with LO=Î¸râ¢uâˆ—3â¢(Îºâ¢gâ¢q0)âˆ’1subscriptğ¿ğ‘‚subscriptğœƒğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¢3superscriptğœ…ğ‘”subscriptğ‘01L_{O}=\theta_{r}u_{*}^{3}(\kappa gq_{0})^{-1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Îº italic_g italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the well-known Obukhov length (cases S6, S7 and T4, see Table 1). Details on this resolution study are provided in Appendix 1, where it is concluded that the mesh is sufficiently fine for the purpose of this study. Specifically, mean profiles are shown to be hardly affected by doubling of the grid resolution, and surface fluxes change less than 2.5%.

2.4.3 Two Reference Simulations

In addition to the simulations discussed above, two reference simulations are included which provide the ability to compare results to well-known cases from literature. First, the GABLS1 case was run, as was already used previously to validate the SP-Wind code for SBLs (see Allaerts (2016) for more details). Note that the same grid spacing was used here as in the other simulations. Secondly, to validate our code against a previous simulation that included subsidence, we ran the â€˜Weakly Stable Boundary Layer (WSBL)â€™ case from L19. Both our GABLS1 and â€˜WSBL-B24â€™ simulations are also included in Table 1. Additionally, the external parameters and bulk quantities from the WSBL and VSBL (Very Stable Boundary Layer) cases from L19 are reported in the last two rows. Of importance, cases from L19 employ a substantially larger global temperature difference of 25 K, while the subsidence rate lies in between our cases S4 and S5. The only difference between the WSBL and VSBL case is the geostrophic wind speed, which is reduced from 12 m/s to 3.5 m/s, thereby effectively increasing the Buoyancy number and lowering the surface Rossby number. More details on the WSBL-B24 and WSBL-L19 simulations, along with a comparison of mean profiles, is provided in Appendix 2. In general, the comparison yielded satisfactory results, especially when taking into account that the MicroHH code used by L19 employs a different discretization method and SGS model.

3 Results

3.1 Overview of Mean Profiles

The effect of each of the governing parameters in Eq. (9) is explored by discussing the horizontal- and time-averaged profiles of momentum, temperature and their respective fluxes for sets S, T and Z as displayed in Fig. 2. In all cases, the velocity magnitude M=(âŸ¨uâŸ©2+âŸ¨vâŸ©2)1/2ğ‘€superscriptsuperscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘¢2superscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘£212M=(\langle u\rangle^{2}+\langle v\rangle^{2})^{1/2}italic_M = ( âŸ¨ italic_u âŸ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âŸ¨ italic_v âŸ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT shows a supergeostrophic wind speed of about 9 m/s. This so-called low-level jet (LLJ) is often observed in both simulations and observations of the (stably) stratified atmosphere, and can have many possible causes (Stull 1988; Mahrt 1999). The formation of the LLJ in idealized LES of the SBL is often related to the inertial oscillation due to the Coriolis force. However, the LLJ in the present simulations is stationary. From the top row, it is evident that increasing subsidence rate decreases the height of the LLJ and the near-surface shear, whereas wind veer is increased. In addition, stronger subsidence reduces the turbulent vertical momentum flux Ï„z=(âŸ¨Ï„xâ¢zâŸ©2+âŸ¨Ï„yâ¢zâŸ©2)1/2subscriptğœğ‘§superscriptsuperscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğœğ‘¥ğ‘§2superscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğœğ‘¦ğ‘§212\tau_{z}=(\langle\tau_{xz}\rangle^{2}+\langle\tau_{yz}\rangle^{2})^{1/2}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( âŸ¨ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âŸ¨ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (with Ï„iâ¢z=uiâ€²â¢wâ€²+Ï„iâ¢zsâ¢gâ¢ssubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘§superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–â€²superscriptğ‘¤â€²superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘ ğ‘”ğ‘ \tau_{iz}={u_{i}^{\prime}w^{\prime}}+\tau_{iz}^{sgs}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_g italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e. the sum of resolved and subgrid shear stress) and increases the surface heat flux q0subscriptğ‘0q_{0}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For low subsidence rates, there is a well-mixed layer with almost constant temperature capped by a strong inversion layer, resembling the widely studied â€˜Conventionally Neutral Boundary Layerâ€™ (CNBL) profile with zero free-atmosphere stratification (Liu etÂ al. 2021b, and references therein). As subsidence rate increases, the height of this capping inversion decreases, and eventually the temperature gradient becomes more or less constant throughout the boundary layer for the cases with strongest subsidence.

The second row of Fig. 2 shows the mean profiles for set T, where the temperature difference Î”â¢Î¸Î”ğœƒ\mathrm{\Delta}\thetaroman_Î” italic_Î¸ between the free-stream and the surface is varied (see panel i). Effects of increasing Î”â¢Î¸Î”ğœƒ\mathrm{\Delta}\thetaroman_Î” italic_Î¸ on the profiles of momentum are qualitatively similar to rising subsidence rate, i.e. the LLJ height descends, wind turns more sharply and surface stress decreases. Regarding the thermal profiles (panels i and j), the height of the inversion layer decreases while the surface heat flux increases.

The effect of surface roughness (or Rossby number) on mean profiles is presented in the bottom row of Fig. 2. It is evident that a rougher surface enhances turbulence generation and therefore increases vertical fluxes of momentum and heat, and the height of the LLJ. The temperature profiles seem unaltered in the lower part of the boundary layer, whereas only the height of the inversion layer increases with larger z0subscriptğ‘§0z_{0}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The grey dashed line in panels k-o, representing the GABLS1 case, displays roughly similar profiles to case C4, which has equal z0subscriptğ‘§0z_{0}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that for the temperature profile, Î¸âˆ=266subscriptğœƒ266\theta_{\infty}=266italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 266 K is estimated to match the top of the inversion layer in the GABLS1 case with our simulations with subsidence (see also 5). The main deviation is in the vertical heat flux qzsubscriptğ‘ğ‘§q_{z}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is approximately linear in the GABLS1 case, in agreement with local scaling (Nieuwstadt 1984), while in our case the equilibrium equation (1) is satisfied (as further discussed in Sect. 3.3).

3.2 Stable Boundary-Layer Depth

In order to scale the vertical coordinate of the mean profiles in Fig. 2, a length scale that characterizes the SBL depth is required. As the SBL often blends smoothly into the residual layer above, accurately measuring its height is difficult, resulting in the existence of numerous estimation approaches (Stull 1988, see e.g. p. 503). Based on LES and field observations, semi-empirical formulas have been proposed to calculate the SBL depth from other flow characteristics (Zilitinkevich and Baklanov 2002; Zilitinkevich etÂ al. 2007). 3.3 Scaling of Steady Mean Profiles

In order to assess similarity of mean variables, Fig. 5 presents scaled profiles of the simulations reported in TableÂ 1. The horizontal velocity magnitude is scaled with the geostrophic wind GğºGitalic_G (Fig. 5a), temperature is normalized with the global temperature difference Î”â¢Î¸Î”ğœƒ\mathrm{\Delta}\thetaroman_Î” italic_Î¸ (Fig. 5c), while the vertical momentum- and heat fluxes are normalized with their respective surface values ( Figs. 5b, d). The thermal boundary-layer height hÎ¸subscriptâ„ğœƒh_{\theta}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is used to normalize the vertical coordinate. Panel a) shows not only that the height where the LLJ occurs coincides in most cases (cf. Fig. 3), but also that the maximum wind speed is roughly equal (âˆ¼1.1â¢Gsimilar-toabsent1.1ğº\sim 1.1Gâˆ¼ 1.1 italic_G). The maximum wind speed is slightly lower for the cases with strongest subsidence (darker blue lines), while the LLJ is slightly stronger for the GABLS1 case (âˆ¼1.2â¢Gsimilar-toabsent1.2ğº\sim 1.2Gâˆ¼ 1.2 italic_G, dashed grey line). The scaled momentum flux profiles in Fig. 5b coincide remarkably well, even with the GABLS1 case.

In line with the observations in the preceding section, only the the cases with strongest subsidence rate clearly deviate from the other profiles, i.e. the height where the shear stress vanishes is significantly higher than the depth of the thermal boundary layer. Since the temperature gradient above hÎ¸subscriptâ„ğœƒh_{\theta}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is negligible, this â€˜decouplingâ€™ of the thermal and turbulent boundary layer implies that a large portion of the turbulent motions is not damped by stratification. Figure 10e in Appendix 1 shows that in these cases, the gradient Richardson number in the thermal boundary layer does not reach the critical value of 0.250.25~{}0.250.25, which offers an explanation for the survival of turbulence and its penetration high into the domain (Sullivan etÂ al. 2016, e.g.).

Figures 5c and d reveal that the shape of the normalized temperature and heat flux profiles is mainly determined by the subsidence rate Î“wsubscriptÎ“ğ‘¤\mathrm{\Gamma}_{w}roman_Î“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as the blue curves clearly do not overlap. By contrast, the green and red curves, which indicate that the global temperature difference (or ğµğ‘¢ğµğ‘¢\mathit{Bu}italic_Bu) and surface roughness (or ğ‘…ğ‘œ0subscriptğ‘…ğ‘œ0\mathit{Ro_{0}}italic_Ro start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) are varied, appear to be very similar. This finding is corroborated by L19, who remark that the temperature profiles in their WSBL and VSBL cases (where Î wsubscriptÎ ğ‘¤\mathrm{\Pi}_{w}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remains equal while both ğµğ‘¢ğµğ‘¢\mathit{Bu}italic_Bu and ğ‘…ğ‘œ0subscriptğ‘…ğ‘œ0\mathit{Ro_{0}}italic_Ro start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are changed, see Table 1) have the same overall shape. As discussed in the previous section, weak subsidence results in a nearly neutral boundary layer with strong capping inversion, whereas high subsidence rates result in a seemingly exponential (convex) temperature profile. The former â€˜convex-concave-convexâ€™ shape was also observed by L19, while the field observations, where they compared their simulations to, showed more convex or linear temperature profiles. They attributed this discrepancy to the lack of a radiation model or erroneous subsidence profile and magnitude. The present results demonstrate that a higher subsidence rate indeed leads to a more convex or linear temperature profile.

To quantify the shape of the temperature profile, the shape factor SÎ¸subscriptğ‘†ğœƒS_{\theta}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as defined in Eq. (5) is used. Figure 6 displays SÎ¸subscriptğ‘†ğœƒS_{\theta}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all simulations as a function of Î w1/2superscriptsubscriptÎ ğ‘¤12\mathrm{\Pi}_{w}^{1/2}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The good collapse of all cases from simulation sets T and Z (green and red markers) re-emphasizes that the scaled temperature profile is mainly determined by the dimensionless subsidence rate Î w=Î“w/fcsubscriptÎ ğ‘¤subscriptÎ“ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘“ğ‘\mathrm{\Pi}_{w}=\mathrm{\Gamma}_{w}/f_{c}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Î“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For small subsidence rates, the shape factor approaches 1, as the scaled temperature profile has a rectangular shape with a thin inversion layer capping the near-neutral boundary layer (see Fig. 5c). For Î wâ†’0â†’subscriptÎ ğ‘¤0\mathrm{\Pi}_{w}\rightarrow 0roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ 0 and SÎ¸â†’1â†’subscriptğ‘†ğœƒ1S_{\theta}\rightarrow 1italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ 1, the temperature gradient in the inversion layer would go to infinity. Therefore, there should be a physical upper limit on SÎ¸subscriptğ‘†ğœƒS_{\theta}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Î wsubscriptÎ ğ‘¤\mathrm{\Pi}_{w}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for which equilibrium is still possible, which it is expected to depend on a critical Richardson number in the inversion layer. Exploring this limit with LES however would require very fine grid resolutions in the strongly stratified inversion layer, which is beyond the scope of the present work (see also Appendix 1). On the other hand, increasing subsidence rate reduces the shape factor, which seems to go asymptotically towards 0 as shown by Fig.Â 6 (although it can be derived that in the limit of laminar flow, SÎ¸â‰ˆ0.31subscriptğ‘†ğœƒ0.31S_{\theta}\approx 0.31italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰ˆ 0.31 (see below), as indicated by the horizontal dotted line).

Considering the normalized heat flux profiles in Fig. 5d, a similar statement can be made, i.e. the Buoyancy and Rossby number only have a small effect while subsidence rate mainly determines the shape of the profiles. This analogy is expected, since the equilibrium profiles of temperature and heat flux are directly related through the subsidence rate:

(see also Eq. (2)). The equation above explains for example why the vertical gradient of the turbulent heat flux approaches zero near the surface, as well as the correlation between the strong temperature gradient and large change in turbulent heat flux in the inversion layer.

By contrast, the GABLS1 case (grey dashed line in Fig. 5d), displays a linear heat flux profile. For such a quasi-stationary SBL without subsidence, Nieuwstadt (1984) already derived analytical expressions for the vertical fluxes of heat and momentum. For the heat flux, a linear profile qz/q0=(1âˆ’z/h)subscriptğ‘ğ‘§subscriptğ‘01ğ‘§â„q_{z}/q_{0}=(1-z/h)italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_z / italic_h ), was indeed obtained, in agreement with the LES results of the GABLS1 case. Given that the GABLS1 profile in Fig. 5b approximately follows this equation (e.g. Beare etÂ al. (2006)), and most of the profiles from present simulations have a similar shape; Nieuwstadtâ€™s momentum flux profile describes even the SBL with subsidence reasonably well in most cases. The fact that the heat flux profiles do not match is a consequence of the additional subsidence term in the temperature equation (see Eqs. (2) and (14)), which makes solving the system of equations from Nieuwstadt (1984, see his Appendix) less straightforward. Therefore, we did not succeed in deriving analytical flux profiles by adapting Nieuwstadtâ€™s derivation with an additional subsidence term.

The accuracy of the solution to Eq. (15) is expected to improve by including a height-dependent eddy diffusivity. Due to the large number of assumptions there, we did not find a general parametrization that described the actual Khâ¢(z)subscriptğ¾â„ğ‘§K_{h}(z)italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z ) in the LESs accurately enough to produce solutions to Eq. (2023) for the case without subsidence, remains a topic for future work.

3.4 A Simple Geostrophic Drag Law to Close the Model

From the empirical correlations (12) and (13) that were developed in the preceding section, the surface heat flux and thermal boundary-layer height can be predicted based on the external simulation parameters Î wsubscriptÎ ğ‘¤\mathrm{\Pi}_{w}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğµğ‘¢ğµğ‘¢\mathit{Bu}italic_Bu, if the friction velocity uâˆ—subscriptğ‘¢u_{*}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is provided. A variety of GDLs has been proposed for different conditions, often in complicated formulations with dependencies on internal flow parameters such as boundary-layer height and geostrophic wind direction, and multiple empirical constants (Liu and Stevens 2021; Narasimhan etÂ al. 2023, most recently). Instead, a formulation preferred is one where the dependent variables are fully determined by the relevant independent variables (given in Eq. (9)), following Swinbank (1974). Plots similar to Fig. 9 with height-dependent values of the fluxes, and therefore a local Obukhov length, yield a substantially better collapse (not shown). For this local scaling system, the similarity relations from from Businger etÂ al. (1971) with Î²m/h=4.7subscriptğ›½ğ‘šâ„4.7\beta_{m/h}=4.7italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m / italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 4.7 overestimate the slope, while Î²m/h=3subscriptğ›½ğ‘šâ„3\beta_{m/h}=3italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m / italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3 as suggested previously by Chinita etÂ al. (2022) fits better to the present LES data.

4 Conclusions

The statistically steady stably stratified ABL in the presence of subsidence has been investigated using a set of idealized large-eddy simulations, forced by a constant geostrophic wind G=8ğº8G=8italic_G = 8Â mÂ s-1 and a linearly increasing subsidence velocity profile. By dimensional analysis, we show that the problem is governed by three non-dimensional groups: a surface Rossby number, a Buoyancy number and a dimensionless subsidence rate. To investigate the impact of these external parameters on the SBL, a range of different surface roughness lengths, subsidence rates and surface temperatures is considered. All simulations reached a truly steady state after 12 to 70 hours, where the cooling heat flux at the surface is compensated by the heating due to subsidence, resulting in thermal equilibrium. Hence, the present set of LES experiments extends previous research that showed subsidence can lead to a steady SBL (Mirocha and KosoviÄ‡ 2010; vanÂ der Linden etÂ al. 2019) to a wider and less extreme range of conditions. Moreover, it allows to systematically investigate the impact of each governing parameter separately.

An examination of mean profiles reveals that all cases exhibit a low-level jet and constant temperature above some level. For increasing subsidence rate, the SBL changes from a near-neutral well-mixed layer capped by a strong inversion to a shallow, more stable ABL without capping inversion. Increasing the global temperature difference (i.e. decreasing the surface temperature) increases surface heat flux and reduces the height of the inversion layer, while a higher surface roughness results in a deeper SBL with more turbulence.

The thermal boundary-layer height is a consistent characterization of the SBL depth in thermal equilibrium, and is compared to previously used definitions of boundary-layer height in the SBL. Scaling the mean profiles with this length scale and the surface values results in an agreeable similarity of turbulent shear stress, except in cases with very strong subsidence, where the turbulence penetrates deep into the neutral free atmosphere. The normalized profiles of temperature and heat flux collapse for varying surface roughness or temperature, as their shape is mainly determined by the subsidence rate. Analytical expressions for these scaled mean profiles are derived for constant turbulent eddy-diffusivity Khsubscriptğ¾â„K_{h}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but a more accurate parametrization of Khsubscriptğ¾â„K_{h}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would be required to describe the profiles of the present LES experiments.

From empirical correlations for the stability parameter hÎ¸/LOsubscriptâ„ğœƒsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‚h_{\theta}/L_{O}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, thermal shape factor SÎ¸subscriptğ‘†ğœƒS_{\theta}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a new unidirectional geostrophic drag law, a model is formed that estimates relevant internal flow properties based on the three governing non-dimensional groups. For the present set of LES data, complemented by a weakly and very stable boundary layer case from vanÂ der Linden etÂ al. (2019), the errors in predictions of surface heat flux and friction velocity are shown to be smaller than 5%, while the thermal boundary-layer height is estimated with a 10% accuracy.

A comparison of the dimensionless velocity and temperature gradients of the equilibrium profiles to MOST shows acceptable agreement in the surface layer. Higher up, similarity of non-dimensional temperature gradient is shown to be improved by using a new scaling argument that includes the thermal boundary-layer height and the non-dimensional Buoyancy and subsidence numbers, derived from the mixed scaling argument from Heisel and Chamecki (2023) and the empirical correlation of the stability parameter.

With the present investigation, light is shed on the complex relationship between subsidence, SBL depth, and surface fluxes, as well as the internal distribution of mean profiles of temperature, momentum and their vertical fluxes. Although a truly steady state may be encountered rarely in reality, the present stationary simulations could also be interpreted as an Eulerian view of a continuous transition from e.g. weak to strong subsidence or small to large vertical temperature difference, with each simulation representing a stage of the transition (Chung etÂ al. 2012).

Finally, the steady-state SBL with subsidence could serve as a new benchmark case for LES. Moreover, the same principle of subsidence heating that compensates for surface cooling could be used in DNS of the SBL. The resulting stationary state allows for long averaging times and more formal comparison of multiple experiments (with different grid resolution, SGS models, wind-farm layout etc.) than a transient simulation with strong inertial oscillation such as the GABLS1 case (Sescu and Meneveau 2014; Maronga and Li 2022).

Appendix 1: Resolution Sensitivity

To assess the sensitivity of our LES results to the grid resolution, we ran the three simulations with the strongest stability on a finer grid. These cases will be indicated as S6f, S7f and T4f. The grid size resolution is doubled with repsect to the cases in Table 1, i.e. Î”x=Î”y=1.56subscriptÎ”ğ‘¥subscriptÎ”ğ‘¦1.56\mathrm{\Delta}_{x}=\mathrm{\Delta}_{y}=1.56roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1.56 m in the horizontal directions and Î”z=0.78subscriptÎ”ğ‘§0.78\mathrm{\Delta}_{z}=0.78roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.78 m vertically. For case T4f, the domain height was halved to Lz=200subscriptğ¿ğ‘§200L_{z}=200italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 200 m in order to reduce computational cost. Given that both the momentum and heat flux profiles are constant above hÎ¸â‰ˆ70subscriptâ„ğœƒ70h_{\theta}\approx 70italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰ˆ 70 m (see Fig. 2), it is safe to assume that this does not affect the boundary layer itself. By contrast, the turbulence in cases S6 and S7 penetrates deeper into the free atmosphere (see Figs. 2 and 5), prohibiting to reduce the domain height. We note that these simulations were initialized from instantaneous flow fields of the cases with coarser grid, interpolated towards the finer mesh. Due to the pseudo-spectral discretization, horizontal interpolation was achieved through zero-padding the Fourier transform as explained in e.g. McWilliams etÂ al. (2023). The fine-grid simulations were run for approximately 12 hours to allow the resolved small-scale turbulence to develop and reach a new thermal equilibrium state, after which the next 12.5 hours were used to collect statistics. Hence, the total runtime for each simulation was 24 physical hours.

Figure 10 shows the effect of increasing the grid resolution on the mean profiles of horizontal velocity (a), vertical momentum flux (b), potential temperature (c) and vertical heat flux (d). The differences between the fine and coarse grid cases appear rather limited, indicating that the grid-size used in this study is sufficient. The discrepancies are found to be largest for case T4f, which is also confirmed by comparing the global flow quantities in Table 2. We find that for cases S6 and S7 the impact of doubling the grid resolution on uâˆ—,q0subscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘0u_{*},q_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hÎ¸subscriptâ„ğœƒh_{\theta}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is less than 1.5%, while in case T4f the surface heat flux and thermal boundary-layer height are reduced by approximately 2.5 and 9%, respectively. The reduction of boundary-layer height with increasing grid resolution is a known issue in LES, as discussed elaborately by Maronga and Li (2022). This is exemplified by the resolution sensitivity analysis by L19, which shows a 9% increase of SBL depth in their VSBL case when the grid spacing is raised by a factor 1.5. Following Sullivan etÂ al. (2016), we also compare the gradient Richardson number Râ¢igğ‘…subscriptğ‘–ğ‘”Ri_{g}italic_R italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the different grid resolutions in Fig. 10e. Both N2superscriptğ‘2N^{2}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and S2superscriptğ‘†2S^{2}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and therefore Râ¢igğ‘…subscriptğ‘–ğ‘”Ri_{g}italic_R italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are sensitive to mesh resolution. According to Sullivan etÂ al. As a result, S2superscriptğ‘†2S^{2}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT decreases and Râ¢igğ‘…subscriptğ‘–ğ‘”Ri_{g}italic_R italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sharply increases above the critical value of 0.250.25~{}0.250.25. For the two cases with high subsidence rate, S6 and S7, the critical Richardson number is not reached, allowing turbulence to penetrate higher into the atmosphere as mentioned in Sect. 3.

Matheou and Chung (2014) proposed a criterion for grid convergence based on the resolved TKE, stating that 90% of the TKE should be resolved for convergence of first-order statistics whereas 95% is required for second-order statistics. Fig. 10f displays the ratio between the SGS-TKE and the total TKE (etâ¢oâ¢t=(u~iâ¢u~i)/2+esâ¢gâ¢ssubscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘¡subscript~ğ‘¢ğ‘–subscript~ğ‘¢ğ‘–2subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘”ğ‘ e_{tot}=(\tilde{u}_{i}\tilde{u}_{i})/2+e_{sgs}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_o italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( over~ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / 2 + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_g italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). It is evident that the subgrid contribution reduces when a finer mesh is used. If we ignore the surface layer, the subgrid contribution is smaller than 20% in cases S6 and S7 and smaller than 15% in cases S6f and S7f. Hence, the requirement from Matheou and Chung (2014) is not met, yet given the small differences in Figs. a-d and Table 2, we still judge the grid resolution to be sufficient for the purpose of this study. Figure 10f further shows that in case T4, the SGS-TKE (and thus the subrid flux) goes to zero due to the strong stability in the inversion layer, while in simulation T4f the subrid TKE does not vanish. This is another indication that the inversion layer in case T4 is under-resolved. However, we remark that replacing the data from this coarse-resolution case by that from T4f does not alter any of the qualitative findings reported in the body of this paper. In fact, the normalized temperature and heat flux profiles from case T4f collapse better on the other profiles from set T in Figs. 5c and d (not shown).

The main difference between the MicroHH code used by L19 and the SP-Wind code used here, is the discretization scheme. Motivated by this difference in discretization, case WSBL-B24 was computed with a grid spacing of Î”x=Î”y=1.31subscriptÎ”ğ‘¥subscriptÎ”ğ‘¦1.31\mathrm{\Delta}_{x}=\mathrm{\Delta}_{y}=1.31roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1.31 m and Î”z=0.7subscriptÎ”ğ‘§0.7\mathrm{\Delta}_{z}=0.7roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.7 m, larger than the isotropic grid with Î”=0.7Î”0.7\mathrm{\Delta}=0.7roman_Î” = 0.7 m used by L19. Furthermore, L19 employ a Smagorinsky-Lily type eddy-viscosity model with a wall correction for the mixing length to calculate the subgrid fluxes, whereas the present simulations utilized a closure based on SGS-TKE (see Sect. 2.2).

The initialization procedure used in this study is outlined in Sect. 2.4.1. In case WSBL-B24 we used an initial temperature profile that increased linearly from Î¸ssubscriptğœƒğ‘ \theta_{s}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to Î¸s+25subscriptğœƒğ‘ 25\theta_{s}+25italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 25 K at hi=50subscriptâ„ğ‘–50h_{i}=50italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 50 m, whereas L19 initialized their simulations with a constant temperature and cooled for 25 hours until the final surface temperature was reached. In contrast, case WSBL-B24 was run for 32 physical hours in total, and the averaging window was a full inertial period (â‰ˆ12.5absent12.5\approx 12.5â‰ˆ 12.5 h) in which the heat flux due to subsidence was equal to the surface heat flux.

Figure 11 compares the mean profiles of horizontal velocity, flow angle and temperature for cases WSBL-L19 and WSBL-B24. An online data extractor tool was used to obtain the data from Fig. 5 in L19. These first-order profiles match rather well. For reference, the observational results from the Dome C site in Antarctica, where L19 compare their data to, is also included. Appendix 3: A Short Note on Validity of Moninâ€“Obukhov Similarity Theory as a Boundary Condition in Large-Eddy Simulations with subsidence
